title: Interstate Access Design Explainer
text:
Recentered IV is uncorrelated with latitude and longitude

For \(\text{Interstate Variable}_{c} \in \{ \text{Treatment}_{c}, \text{Recentered IV}_{c}\}\), I run the following regression:
\[\text{Interstate Variable}_{c} = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \frac{\text{Latitude}_c}{100} + \beta_2 \frac{\text{Longitude}_c}{100} + \epsilon_c\]
When I regress latitude and longitude on the recentered instrument, the coefficients are zero.





Go back

title: Raw Data & Employment Growth Regression
text:
The Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956 created the 41,000-mile Interstate system — the largest public works project in U.S. history.
Like most major infrastructure projects, it came with promises of economic development.
In this project, I estimate the causal effect of Interstate access on county employment growth using a new design-based instrumental variable.






Seattle, 1967

title: Raw Data & Employment Growth Regression
text:
The Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956 created the 41,000-mile Interstate system — the largest public works project in U.S. history.
Like most major infrastructure projects, it came with promises of economic development.
In this project, I estimate the causal effect of Interstate access on county employment growth using a new design-based instrumental variable.






Seattle, 1967

Recentered IV does not predict counties pre-Interstate employment growth

For \(\text{Interstate Variable}_{c} \in \{ \text{Treatment}_{c}, \text{Recentered IV}_{c}\}\), I run the following regression:
\[
\log(\text{Employment}_{c, 1950}) - \log(\text{Employment}_{c, 1930})
= \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}\,\text{Interstate Variable}_{c}
+ X_{c}\gamma + \varepsilon_{c}
\]
When I regress employment growth from 1930 to 1950 on the recentered instrument, the coefficient is zero.





Go back

Recentered IV does not predict other pre-Interstate county characteristics

For \(x_{c} \in \{ \text{Population Density}_{c, 1940}, \text{Log House Value}_{c, 1940}, \text{Market Potential}_{c, 1950}\}\) and \(\text{Interstate Variable}_{c} \in \{ \text{Treatment}_{c}, \text{Recentered IV}_{c}\}\) I run the following regression:
\[
x_{c} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}\,\text{Interstate Variable}_{c} + \varepsilon_{c}
\]





Go back

(Recentered IV x High Ag Indicator) does not predict pre-Interstate county characteristics

For \(x_{c} \in \{ \text{Population Density}_{c, 1940}, \text{Log House Value}_{c, 1940}, \text{Market Potential}_{c, 1950}\}\)
\[
x_{c} = \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}(\text{RecenteredIV}_{c}\times \text{High Ag}_{c}) + \beta_{2}\text{RecenteredIV}_{c} + \varepsilon_{c}
\]





Note: I am not worried about that \(*\). If the interacted instrument is truly uncorrelated with counties’ potential outcomes, 1 in 10 tests for this will be rejected at the 10% significance level, by construction of hypothesis testing.


(Recentered IV x High Ag Indicator) does not pre-Interstate employment growth

\[\small
\log(\text{Employment}_{c, 1950}) - \log(\text{Employment}_{c, 1930})
= \beta_{0} + \beta_{1}(\text{RecenteredIV}_{c}\times \text{High Ag}_{c})  + \beta_{2}\text{RecenteredIV}_{c}
+ X_{c}\gamma + \varepsilon_{c}
\]





Go back
